;Among American scholars who study China, Elizabeth Perry has a special life experience: she was born in Shanghai in 1948, and her parents were both Shanghai Saints. Professor at John's University, but her family left China shortly after she was born due to changes in the current situation. She later joked that maybe she had been closely associated with the word "revolution" since she was born, so she has been interested in the Chinese revolution throughout her life. "Without the revolution, I would probably have grown up in China. I have always been curious about the Chinese revolution, and wanted to know why the revolution happened and what consequences it would bring to China."

;

;Pei Yili also spent his youth in China. She survived the surging global "revolutionary" wave of the left-wing movement, which further strengthened her future academic ambitions. After China's door opened, she became one of the first foreign scholars allowed to enter China for fieldwork and research. Her research interests mainly focus on modern popular resistance and grassroots politics, spanning the fields of political science and history. She has written Generous and award-winning, the American Historical Review commented that she "combines a social scientist's love of order with a historian's eye for great stories."

;

;Pei Yili has taught at the University of Arizona, the University of Washington and the University of California, Berkeley. Since 1997, he has taught in the Department of Government of Harvard University. In addition to her teaching work, one of Pei Yili's greatest characteristics lies in her participation in public affairs. She once served as the director of the Fairbank Research Center at Harvard University and the president of the Association for Asian Studies. Since 2008, she has served as the president of the Harvard-Yenching Institute, cultivating a group of outstanding students and scholars for China studies. Our interview took place in the office of the Harvard-Yenching Institute. The office is small, and the black-and-white photos that mark important moments of this academic institution in the past century hung on the wall exude a deep sense of history.

;

;“Since I became president, I have spent half of my time at Harvard-Yenching Institute and the other half as a professor at Harvard.” Pei Yili is still active in teaching, every Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. At 3:30, she is open to students. Each student had to make an appointment with her in advance and explain their questions succinctly. After learning that she had given me more than three hours of interview time, her students all expressed their envy that I had such a "luxury" opportunity.

;

;Pei Yili has a hearty personality and is quick to talk. During the interview, he burst out laughing from time to time. Even if he fell into a gloomy look when recalling the twists and turns of his family's experiences, he would immediately ignore this emotion.

;

;China has undergone too many changes in the past hundred years. This may be what attracts Pei Yili, a political scientist who studies China. "Studying their successes and failures is exciting and fascinating."

;

;;

;

;Pei Yili's parents' wedding photo; (provided by interviewee/picture) ;

;

;Birth under revolutionary fire

;

;"Were you born in China?"

;

;"Yes."

;

;"Why were you born in Red China?"

;

;From the time I was a girl, for a long time, every time I followed the whole family back to the United States, whether at the airport or the dock, Immigration After the officer opened her passport, there was always a conversation like the one above.

;

;“I would say that when I was born it was not red, just a little pink.” More than half a century later, Pei Yili was sitting in his office at the Harvard-Yenching Institute, recalling the past and couldn’t help but He let out a hearty laugh. Then, her expression became solemn. "Yes, my parents both lived in troubled times in China; without the revolution, I would probably have grown up in China, so our family does have constant ties with China."

;

;Pei Yili was born in a He has a strong religious family, and his parents are both missionaries of the Episcopal Church. Her father, Charles Perry - Pei Yili later learned that his Chinese name was Pan Xuesi - had studied Chinese and Japanese at Harvard University in his early years and had a special liking for East Asia. In 1931, Pan Xuesi traveled across the ocean and arrived in Shanghai to teach at St. John's University. St. John's University was founded in 1879, formerly known as St. John's College. It is sponsored by the Episcopal Church in the United States and is the earliest church university in China. After the September 18th Incident broke out, Pan Xuesi made a special trip to Northeast China. "He also wrote a very interesting diary about his travel experience in Manchuria. He was very interested in this period of history."

;

;Pan Xuesi met his future wife Kai Rui (;Note: the Chinese name is Kong Kaili;) in China. Both later taught at St. John's University. Interestingly, Pei Yili never heard his parents communicate in Chinese when he was a child, "because his father only knew Mandarin and his mother only knew Shanghainese."

;

;;

;

;Bae Yi-ri and her father as a girl;(provided by interviewee/picture);

;

;Pei Yili’s parents got married in the summer of 1937. Because Pan Xuesi has been interested in Japanese culture for a long time, he chose to go to Japan for his honeymoon. "When they were on their honeymoon, they heard the news about Japan's invasion of China, but they didn't dare to confirm it, so they went to the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo to ask whether the rumors were true. The embassy staff may not want to take responsibility and did not tell them the truth. They just said : No, there is no problem in China now. You can go back to China! So they boarded the ship from Nagasaki back to Shanghai as originally planned."

;

;Pei Yili said that his father liked water sports when he was young and was very fond of boats. The performance is very clear. Not long after their ship left Japanese port, my father became acutely aware that something was not quite right. He said to his wife: "Strange, why is the waterline of the ship so low?" He ran to the bottom to find out what was going on, and found that the bottom was full of Japanese soldiers with live ammunition.

;

;Obviously, the soldiers Pei Yili's parents met back then were the regiments that had been reinforced from Japan after the Battle of Songhu began - they had inadvertently become witnesses of history. As soon as these soldiers on the same ship arrived in Shanghai, they joined the war of aggression against China and became a link in the brutal machine. What awaited the young couple who returned from their honeymoon was Shanghai burned by the war. "My mother later recalled that when the ship entered Shanghai, she could smell the smell of dead people everywhere. This was something she had never experienced..." The parents returned to their residence at St. John's University and discovered that they were married. The chapel has been attacked by the Japanese army, the home has been ransacked, and all the wedding gifts have been stolen by Japanese soldiers.

;

;Due to the current situation, the mother left Shanghai and returned to the United States for a while with her newborn son, while the father chose to stay at St. John's University. In 1941, the "Pearl Harbor Incident" broke out, the Japanese army invaded the concession, and Shanghai fell completely. Except for those who have returned to China, the rest of the foreign teachers at St. John's University were imprisoned in concentration camps, including Pei Yili's father. He was not released back to the United States until two years later when the U.S. and Japanese governments exchanged detainees. When his grandmother picked him up at the New York port, she could no longer recognize her emaciated son. But before long, Pan Xuesi hoped to return to China again. "With the help of the U.S. Navy, he returned to China as he wished and helped the National Government fight the Japanese."

;

;In 1945, after World War II ended, his mother also returned to China. For this family, this was a brief peaceful time in China - Pei Yili, who was born in Shanghai in September 1948, was the fruit of this life.

;

;In 1949, the Chinese Communist revolution had reached a decisive moment. "My mother took me and my two brothers and left China first, but my father once again wanted to stay." A few months later, the situation became even more turbulent. Pan Xuesi had no choice but to bid farewell to the country where he had lived on and off for 18 years.

;

;After returning to the United States, Pan Xuesi returned to the university where he once studied and taught for several years, but the distant East has always been a place he has never forgotten. In 1951, their family moved to Tokyo, and Pan Xuesi taught at Rikkyo University, founded by the Anglican Church.

;

;On Thanksgiving night in 1959, the whole family was sitting together to eat and celebrate this traditional American holiday. Suddenly, they heard the dog barking in the yard. My father went out to check, but an accident happened unexpectedly.

;

;"Two young Japanese students came in drunk. They both practiced karate... It only took a few minutes to beat my father to death... There was no plan to attack me. My father's, they were completely drunk at the time and didn't know who my father was."

;

;This American, who had a strong interest and concern for the East throughout his life, ended his life in a sad way life.

;

;After her father died, her mother used her understanding of the world to deal with the tragedy - although her way of handling it may not be understood by most people: instead of asking for a heavy sentence for the two Japanese students, she Instead, he interceded for them. As a result, one of them was released and the other was sentenced. During his sentence, his mother not only visited him frequently, but also went to the court to fight for a commutation of his sentence. The young man only stayed in prison for two or three years before regaining his freedom.

;

;My mother and her family lived in Japan for several more years until they returned to the United States in 1962.

;

;;

;

;In 1981, Pei Yili took a photo with the interviewee in Songjiang;(Photo provided by the interviewee);

;

;Political Awareness

;

;Popular protests were one of her later academic interests and directions. Her initial perceptual understanding of this came from her early experience in Japan. In the early 1950s, the Communist Party of Japan and the Socialist Party of Japan would organize labor protests every May Day. That day, Pei Yili's father happened to pass by. When the protesters saw the American, they started knocking on his car window. The car was surrounded by crowds... After his father returned home, his family found that almost all the car windows were broken, and The shocked father was almost shaking. After calming down, the father tried to explain to his daughter what "May Day" was and what those people were protesting... This made little Pei Yili become very interested in this form of popular protest.

;

;On June 11, 1960, nearly 6 million Japanese took to the streets to protest against the new Japan-US security treaty. The US Embassy in Japan was surrounded by nearly 200,000 Japanese protesters. Among this huge crowd of protesters was 12-year-old Pei Yili. She skipped school, took to the streets, and participated in demonstrations against the Japan-US security treaty. In Pei Yili's understanding, the essence of this event is not "anti-American" but in support of peace. "People seem to be very happy to have an American child participating."

;

;In a sense, this is her The first time she participated in a "mass movement" was also the first time she experienced the power of mass movements - the bulletproof car in which the then US Ambassador to Japan Hagerty was also surrounded by demonstrators, and the ambassador himself had to sneak in through the back door. Eisenhower, who was scheduled to visit Japan on June 19, had to postpone his visit indefinitely.

;

;As a child, Pei Yili also curiously observed that in some protests, the expressions of the people were very similar to the rituals of celebrating religious festivals. For example, during religious festivals in Japan - similar to China, people will take part in a procession with a sedan chair in which a god sits and then moves around in a kind of snake dance. "I liked this kind of ritual so much that I often attended Japanese folk festivals in our neighborhood. Part of my interest in political protest in Japan also came from this kind of folk ritual."

;

;This early experience, later It became a unique perspective for her to observe political activities. For example, during her investigation into Anyuan, Jiangxi, one of the birthplaces of the Chinese revolution, she discovered how Li Lisan wisely used traditional techniques to achieve the purpose of mobilizing workers to participate in the revolution: On May 1st, International Labor Day, Li Lisan organized a workers' march. "In the procession, there was a large sedan carried by eight people. Generally speaking, in this kind of local celebration, the sedans are carried by the gods of the earth and other folk religions, but this time, inside the sedan was a statue of Marx. Like." This detail was used by Pei Yili to analyze the relationship between national political mobilization and traditional culture.

;

;In 1965, 16-year-old Pei Yili entered William Smith College. She was quickly thrust into another turbulent political environment. Pei Yili later concluded: "Although my intuitive interest in popular protest comes from my experience in Japan, my left-wing thoughts come more from my college days." She was very active in college and participated in sailing clubs, drama clubs, Political Club...but "politics" was her more enduring interest and more devoted concern. She remembers riding the bus to Washington with college classmates to march in front of the Pentagon to protest the Vietnam War.

;

;It was also during this time that the seemingly weak connection between her and China, where she was born, became stronger in some way. William Smith College is small, but it has a "Mao Zedong Thought Study Group", of which Pei Yili is a member. She studied Mao Zedong Thought with her classmates and developed a strong interest in Chinese politics. Soon, she became determined to learn Chinese.

;

;But there were no Chinese classes at her university, so she could only start learning Chinese by herself with the help of a tape recorder and a few tapes in the library. She asked the school if she could get credits for self-study in Chinese. The school’s answer: We don’t have Chinese classes, how can we evaluate your learning level and give you credits? Unwilling to give up easily, Pei Yili proposed to the school: "If I learn by myself to a certain extent, I can ask a Cornell professor to test me. If I pass, can I get credits?" The school had no choice but to agree.

;

;Pei Yili later contacted a professor at Cornell University, who said: You should study by yourself for three months through tapes and language books, and then come to Cornell to take my test. Three months later, Pei Yili successfully passed the exam. Interestingly, she later went to Taipei to study Chinese for a period of time. The Chinese teacher in Taipei grew up in Beijing. She was very surprised by the American student’s accent. One time she couldn’t help but ask: “Where does your accent come from?” Are you here? Is your teacher in the United States from the Northeast?" "I deny it. I want to say that my teacher is a 'recorder' and not a Northeastern, but at that time I didn't know how to say the word 'recorder'!" Recalling this incident , Pei Yili was overjoyed.

;

;The Chinese name "Pei Yili" was given while studying in Taipei. Much later, when she was looking at her father's book and saw the Chinese stamp on it, she discovered that her father's Chinese name was "Pan Xuesi". "So my surname should be Pan instead of Pei." Speaking of this matter, Pei Yili showed a trace of regret.

;

;;

;

;Pursuit The Origin of the Chinese Revolution

;

;When he was studying for a doctorate in political science at the University of Michigan, Pei Yili's original idea was to use China's "Cultural Revolution" as the topic of his doctoral thesis, but he was opposed by a supervisor. The teacher thinks the time is not yet ripe. She instead determined to explore the origins of the Chinese revolution using perspectives and methods that were different from the prevailing views at the time.

;

;“How to understand the peasant revolution is an issue that has been ignored by many scientific scholars who pay attention to peasant issues.” When explaining the motivation for her research, she said, “Peasants entered world history in the face of revolution. This fact of the stage has fueled the development of many social science theories that attempt to explain the causes of peasant rebellions. Anthropologists, historians, sociologists, and political scientists have all come up with their own answers to this important question.";

;At this time, Pei Yili has revealed her "academic ambition": she decided to examine the relationship between rebels and revolutionaries through the study of a region. The plan had to be concentrated in an area that had both a tradition of peasant rebellion and a pre-1949 Communist base. She chose this area in Huaibei. Huaibei was also the center of the famous White Lotus Sect, a loose folk religious organization that launched many rebellions in the region.

;

;At that time, China’s door was still locked. Like other scholars, she chose to go to the National Palace Museum in Taipei to look at archives. During this period, she also went to Japan to collect information in a library in Tokyo. .

;

;“I was so young and naive at the time, and had no idea how difficult this topic was—otherwise I would never have been stupid enough to choose this direction for my thesis.” There was another hearty laugh. Although she was fortunate to receive help from many people, including several American historians who were doing research there who gave her a lot of advice, Professor Albert Feuerwerker, another famous scholar of Chinese history at the University of Michigan, was also careful She was told the location of various Ming and Qing archives, but, "I had no idea that the original sources on this subject were so scattered and their types were so different."

;

;Another barrier was language. Although she systematically studied Chinese, including classical Chinese, for two years when she was a graduate student, she had never received special training in reading Qing Dynasty documents like those historians from the United States. So when she saw the Qing Dynasty archives at the National Palace Museum in Taipei for the first time, she was almost overwhelmed by despair: "I will never be able to understand these archives!" In her reply, the instructor said in a tone that could not be flinched: "You have to completely Do research on original archives, and you have to read everything." Pei Yili also knew that the instructor did not understand classical Chinese and had no idea of ​​the difficulty of reading and sorting out Ming and Qing archives, but she still followed his advice. There was no way out now. She found that after really getting into it, she was completely capable of reading those files. "We can see almost all the original documents you know in Taipei back then. For example, you can take the memorial written by the governor of Guangdong and Guangxi to Xianfeng, which contains the instructions of Emperor Xianfeng, 'I understand.' When you feel this way , it doesn’t matter how obscure the file content is.”

;

;Relying on solid work, Pei Yili completed her doctoral thesis. In 1980, the monograph "Rebels and Revolutionaries in North China" based on the thesis was published at Stanford University. This monograph is regarded as the representative work of the third generation of overseas Chinese scholars. Pei Yili dedicated his first book to his parents, "Without them, I would not be engaged in Chinese studies."

;

;;

;

;Return to China

;

;"Were you born in China?" Every time I return to the United States, I enter the customs Shi's cross-examination once made Pei Yili feel like a "second-class American." This scene did not change until 1972, the year President Nixon visited China. Pei Yili remembers very clearly that when she returned from a trip to Japan that year and entered the United States, as usual, the immigration officer opened her passport and asked this question as expected, and Pei Yili answered in the affirmative as usual.

;

;"I was waiting for the next question: 'Why were you born in Red China?' But unexpectedly, this time the other person's reaction was: 'Oh, that's amazing! Can you speak Chinese?' I said : 'Yes, I will say a little bit.' He said: 'Our country needs people like you.' That was the first time I was happy that I was born in China."

;

;中After the thaw in U.S. relations, the National Committee on Us-China Relations began to send delegations to visit China one after another. Each delegation was accompanied by a scholar who studies China to help members understand China. In June 1979, Pei Yili was selected to join the delegation of big city mayors in the United States. She visited cities such as Shanghai, Beijing, Nanjing, Guangzhou and Hangzhou, and saw the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, and the West Lake with her own eyes... She was extremely excited. "I get up early every day and go to the park to talk to the local people. I like this feeling very much." But on the other hand, she felt that the China she saw was not the China that was filled with revolutionary and romantic imagination before. Pei Yili also went to Shanghai to find their old house at St. John's University, took many photos of the campus, and brought them back to the United States to show his mother. Not surprisingly, my mother was extremely shocked and also extremely sad.

;

;A few months later, Pei Yili came to China again. This time she was a visiting scholar and was given the opportunity to study in China for a year - she was also the first group allowed to enter China for fieldwork. One of the foreign scholars who studied it, Zhou Xirui and Huang Zongzhi came to China at the same time as her, and they later became the backbone of overseas Chinese studies. She also experienced the "voucher era" under the planned economy. "We treated each other as comrades and often quoted Chairman Mao's quotations in debates on academic and political issues." But behind the revolutionary upsurge, she gradually discovered Another side. For example, as a foreigner, she can sit on a soft sleeper, which ordinary Chinese people cannot enjoy; there are very few restaurants open to the outside world, but "visiting scholars" like her can enjoy "special offerings" in special areas of restaurants, which ordinary Chinese people cannot enjoy. Not enough, and can't afford it. In the spring of 1980, accompanied by Professor Cai Shaoqing of Nanjing University, Pei Yili went to Anhui for her first investigation. The field visits in Guoyang and Mengcheng gave her a more personal experience of the real life in rural China.

;

;One year, when Pei Yili came to Shanghai for a meeting, she met Zhang Zhongli, then president of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences. Zhang graduated from St. John's University in his early years and happened to be her father's student at that time. After meeting, they introduced each other to the work they were doing. After hearing Pei Yili's work plan for the next book, Zhang Zhongli joked: "You are from Shanghai - I saw your father holding you on campus many years ago. Why not write the story of Shanghai?"< /p>;

;Under Zhang Zhongli’s suggestion, since the 1990s, Pei Yili’s research focus has shifted from the distant countryside of Huaibei to the world metropolis of Shanghai, and his research focus has also changed from the study of peasant revolution issues to the study of the labor movement. She completed the monograph "Shanghai Strike: A Study of Chinese Workers' Politics". In this book, she also used a lot of pen and ink to write about Du Yuesheng and Huang Jinrong, figures who are no strangers to us, and explored their roles in the labor movement. Some real characters. This book won the 1993 Fairbank Medal of the American Historical Association. The American Historical Review commented that she combines "a social scientist's love of order" with "a historian's eye for capturing exciting stories." When writing this book, Pei Yili conducted a detailed investigation and analysis of the working class involved, including British American Tobacco. When she was about to finish the book, she suddenly realized that the British American Tobacco Company's factory in Pudong was the concentration camp where her father was imprisoned. "I did not expect that the object of my research was to some extent closely related to the history of my own family. So I later wrote in the first sentence of the preface to the English version of "Shanghai Strike": 'To me For me, writing this book feels like coming home.'"

;

;;

;

;Pei Yili and Nanjing University Professor Zhou Xiaohong visited the Anhui History Museum; (Provided by interviewee/picture);

;

;Cannot forget the "big problem"

;

;In fact, both the early interest in peasant revolution and the later shift to urban workers The study of movements, those revolutions that changed the fate of countless people, has always been a major issue that Pei Yili is concerned about. In an interview, the famous historian Zhou Xirui mentioned this detail: In 2007, when Pei Yili was elected president of the Asian Studies Association, he said, "We cannot forget the Chinese revolution, these big topics, and how to understand China. How did the big change happen?" Zhou Xirui later gave Pei Yili one of his monographs and asked her for advice. Pei Yili wrote back to him, saying once again: "We should think more about China's big problems." - This is actually Pei Yili's expectation for contemporary scholars doing Chinese studies, and it is also her constant warning to herself.

;

;In addition to academic research, Pei Yili also actively participates in public affairs and social activities. In 1999, not long after arriving at Harvard University, Pei Yili became the director of the Fairbank Center for China Studies, a major center for overseas Chinese studies. Before her name, there are a series of famous scholars such as Fairbank, Schwartz, Kong Feili, Vogel, etc. Since 2008, Pei Yili has become the head of another important academic institution-the president of the Harvard-Yenching Institute. As one of the most famous academic exchange institutions between China and the West, Harvard-Yenching has had seven presidents since its founding in 1928. From Ye Lizui, Reischauer to Du Weiming, each of them is a highly respected scholar. Pei Yili’s status and influence in the academic world are evident.

;

;The focus of Pei Yili's research is "Chinese Revolution", which may be a bit "non-mainstream" in the Western academic circles of China studies. Therefore, when she was interviewed by reporters after being elected, she also expressed her feelings: "For a long time, there were only a dozen or so people in the United States who specialized in studying the Chinese revolution. In recent years, there have been more and more people studying the Chinese revolution. Mao Zedong , the 'Great Leap Forward', the 'Cultural Revolution', the Anti-Japanese War... have all become popular." She joked: "Otherwise, a guy like me who studies obscure topics probably wouldn't be the new president of Harvard-Yenching!";

;After the door between China and the United States opens and China reintegrates into the world family, commercial and economic revival and prosperity may be the most obvious and direct result. But what Pei Yili feels more is its huge significance in knowledge and academic exchanges. Over the past century or so, from the Qing Empire to the Republic of China, and then to the People's Republic of China, too many changes have taken place in this land. This may be what attracted Pei Yili to study China, "They are so Complex, yet so fascinating."

;In response to online reports that "more than 30,000 Chinese locust trees were forcibly cut down in Danfeng County, Shaanxi Province", the local government has established a An investigation team composed of the County Agriculture and Rural Affairs Bureau, County Resources Bureau, County Forestry Bureau and other units conducted on-site investigations. Relevant departments in Danfeng County released the following investigation results on November 11.

;

;After investigation, the location where the problem was reported is located in Taizimiao Village, Caichuan Town, Danfeng County. On July 3, 2023, Caichuan Town received the "Rectification Order for Suspected Pattern Issues of Permanent Basic Farmland" from the Tianchang Office of Danfeng County. It reported that three satellite patches in Taizimiao Village were suspected of illegally occupying permanent basic farmland and requested rectification within a time limit. . After field investigation, it was found that walnut trees and Sophora japonica were planted on the farmland involved in the feedback map, which was indeed an illegal occupation of permanent basic farmland.

;

;After receiving the rectification notice, town and village staff repeatedly publicized the farmland protection policy to the people involved, mobilized cooperation and support for farmland protection work, and in accordance with the laws and regulations of the "Land Management Law" and "Basic Farmland Protection Regulations", A notice for rectification within a time limit was issued on the spot, and three people refused to make rectification within a time limit. Subsequently, town and village cadres visited the plot many times to help with sales and reduce losses to the masses. However, due to the high density of seedlings planted and the occurrence of dry rot in large areas, no company purchased it. After that, town and village cadres came to communicate with each other many times without success, and the above three people refused to make rectifications within a time limit. On November 2, the Caichuan Town Government, together with the County Agricultural Law Enforcement Brigade, cleared and replanted walnut trees and Sophora japonica seedlings illegally planted on permanent basic farmland. Because planting seedlings on the involved plots of land is illegal and illegal, occupying permanent basic farmland, no compensation matters are involved.

;The 58th Golden Bell ended at the end of October At the awards, you can see the grand fight between gods in Taiwanese dramas: "Copycat", "Her and Her", "A Rampage Female Surgeon Comes to the Village"... There are many excellent products and the competition is fierce.

;

;In fact, Taiwanese dramas have shown a trend of comprehensive revival and diversification of genres since 2019, completely reversing the decline caused by the decline of idol dramas around 2010.

;

;How does it get out of today's new situation? Today, let’s talk about the past ten years of Taiwanese drama.

;

;Involution: The self-rescue of a veteran TV personality

;

;In the minds of many viewers, Taiwanese dramas were once equated with "idol dramas". After the millennium, youthful idol dramas such as "Meteor Garden", "Prince Turns into a Frog", "Mischief Kiss", "Princess Little Sister" and "Destined to Love You" dominate the airwaves, with an innocent and dreamy style that is earthy and sweet. It captured the hearts of many young audiences and became many people’s youth memories.

;

;;

;

;;

;

;But the good times lasted less than ten years. Due to copy-paste and audience fatigue, Taiwanese dramas have entered a period of depression and depression. Idol dramas cannot produce new ideas, local dramas cannot retain audiences, and coupled with the outflow of talent, Taiwanese dramas are in a precarious situation.

;

;In 2014, the well-known TV personality Wang Xiaodi joined forces with eight directors including Tsai Ming-liang, Chen Yuxun, and Qu Youning to establish a company and launched the "Theater Planting" and "QPlace" plans, aiming to build a platform to "give access to It is a space where writers, actors, directors and post-production staff with ideas can be nourished and developed."

;

;"Zhi Theater" is mainly divided into four sections: love growth, thriller mystery, horror and supernatural, and drama adaptation. Dramas such as "Love Sandstorm", "Twilight", "Please Close Your Eyes after Dark" and "Sixties Boy Turns Adult" have launched the first shot of innovation in Taiwanese dramas.

;

;"Tumi" was born out of an idol love drama, mixing elements of parallel time and space to explore different directions of love stories. It is indeed innovative at the time of 2016.

;

;;

;

;"The Sixtieth Century Boy" "Become an Adult" and "Love Sandstorm" are rooted in family dramas, focusing on the daily style that touches people with emotion, less of the horse-grabbing style of "Taiwan Acheng" and "Unforgettable", and more of the warmth of the flow of life. In the face of traditional Taiwanese dramas that often have 40 or 200 episodes, the small-scale short drama model of "Zhitheater" appears to be the essence of the drama.

;

;;

;

;“植剧场”采用明星带新星模式，启用吴慷仁、杨丞琳、蓝正龙等知名演员，带着他们挖掘的新人一道演戏。如今已星光闪耀的许光汉（《想见你》）、刘冠廷（《火神的眼泪》），以及逐渐在新生代里站稳脚跟的孙可芳（《孤味》）、陈妤（《我们与恶的距离》）等人，都是在这种模式中成长起来的。

;

;;

;

;2022年，“植剧场”升级为“茁剧场”，在原类型剧上加入报告文学与人物传记，筹划拍摄《滴水的推理书屋》《绿岛金魂》《走过爱的蛮荒》《谁说妈妈像月亮》等剧集。

;

;与此同时，老牌电视台也蓄势而发，推动传统题材剧的纵深发展。公视的《一把青》（2015）改编自白先勇的同名短篇小说，由导演编剧修建枝蔓、填补血肉，飞行员家属村的爱恨纠葛折射出时代痼疾，谱写了一曲荡气回肠、哀婉动人的年代往事。

;

;;

;

;华视的《俗女养成记》（2019），创下近十年来华视自制剧的最佳成绩。它并置了台北与台南的空间、童年与中年的时间，聚焦于40岁女性的人生选择，完美击中在都市漂泊自嘲为“loser”的观剧群体。

;

;;

;

;TVBS的原创剧集《有生之年》（2023）被称为“男版《俗女》”，讲述了一个失败的中年男子决定去死的故事，治愈暖心，还切合了全职儿女、中年失业等共鸣性社会议题。

;

;;

;

;外卷：流媒体平台的业务拓展

;

;本土发力形成了良性竞争，而向外的业务拓展为则台剧带来了新动能。

;

;近年来，HBO、Netflix、Disney等均大力拓荒海外业务，台湾成为了合拍华语剧的首选地区。

;

;外国流媒体带来的是工业化拍摄模式，快节奏、短剧集、前两集高投资吸引人的美剧风吹到了台湾。用制片人刘瑜萱的话来讲，和成熟的工业模式相比，之前拍剧的方式无异于“土法炼钢”。

;

;HBO是首个在台湾吃螃蟹的流媒体。 2017年它与公视合作了《通灵少女》，这部融合奇幻灵异和少女成长元素的剧集创下了收视奇迹。 2019年双方再度联手，打造扎根现实主义的《我们与恶的距离》，这部从不同立场讨论无差别杀人案的剧集成为了年度爆款。 2020年，底层平民题材的剧集《做工的人》再度掀起热潮。

;

;;

;

;Netflix于2018年推出《你的孩子不是你的孩子》，对东亚教育问题的深入探讨在播出后引发广泛共鸣。 2019年的《罪梦者》、2020年的《谁是被害者》和2023年的《模仿犯》则主打大尺度悬疑，剧集品质不是一流，但热度与话题度齐飞。 2021-2022年的《华灯初上》较好地完成了群像塑造，复古的年代质感和厚重的人生悲剧使其不同于普通奇情剧。

;

;;

;

;FOX提供技术支持的《想见你》是近年来的现象级爆剧，且长尾效应显著，不仅让许光汉跻身一线，还衍生了同名电影。倘若拆解来看，它是在校园台偶剧的基础上做了加法，丝滑地融合了平行时空的奇幻元素，给人耳目一新之感。当然，看到最后，莫比乌斯环一般的叙事线索已经不重要，其底牌仍是擅长以细腻感情动人的本土优势。

;

;;

;

;外国流媒体在题材选择上偏向于类型融合，有时会有堆砌热门元素之感，如集悬疑、犯罪、灵异于一体的《罪梦者》不乏网络热传的高光桥段，但整部剧看下来劳累且混乱。

;

;;

;

;筹备阶段往往是大数据为主导，所以有自以为踩中high点实则不然的黑帮梦幻偶像剧《极道千金》、中西灵异混搭剧《彼岸之嫁》、黑暗悬疑邪教家庭剧《谁在你身边》等不太成功的尝试。

;

;;

;

;观察合拍剧的爆款不难发现：它们皆是较凸显在地元素的剧集，如《我们与恶的距离》改编自台湾社会真实案件，《华灯初上》则触及了日殖时期以后台湾特殊的条通文化。如何在中西文化交手时尽可能地发挥所长，是参与合拍的台湾电视人需考虑的重点。

;

;;

;

;;

;

;除此之外，腾讯、爱奇艺等视频平台也积极开展“出海”策略，向亚洲地区投拍影视剧，文化上同根同源且拥有成熟影视链的台湾无疑占据合作的先机。

;

;大陆视频平台给台湾带来的是产业化行销模式，不会太干预其剧集创作，剧集在视频平台同步播出，引发两岸同追剧的热潮。平台精心挑选有潜质的台湾省新艺人，帮助其拓展岛外业务，似有捧出华语新偶像的计划。

;

;腾讯WeTV推出的《永远的第一名》《第二名的逆袭》是同性题材的标杆。姜瑞智与林子闳等年轻艺人也因此获得了极大关注度。

;

;爱奇艺国际站涉及的类型更多，既有禁忌师生恋题材的《第九节课》，揭露暗网的悬疑犯罪剧《逆局》，还有凸显兄弟CP的灵异奇幻都市剧《不良执念清除师》。

;

;剧集热播后，老牌男神周渝民再度翻红，新晋小生曾敬骅、陈昊森在《刻在你心底的名字》后各自拥有了代表作。

;

;;

;

;总体而论，台剧复兴是多方合力的结果，内部在不断推陈出新，外部也伸来了机会的橄榄枝。

;

;这也使得近年来观看台剧的观众节节攀升，优质台湾艺人的待播剧也往往被高看一眼，寄予更多期待，这便是良性循环的嘉奖。

;

;而当这些优质台剧卷至内娱，我们又该交出一份怎样的答卷呢？

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 18:25:03 +0800 她年少成名，十四年后拍出新片再得大奖http://www.infzm.com/contents/260408
;;2023-11-11 17:00:00;
;

;At the end of August 2023, for the promotion of the movie "It's a Worth It", director Liu Jiayin registered for the first time Weibo. In order to learn how to use it skillfully, she specially asked a friend to teach her online, wrote her first tweet, and left an anxious message to the producer's account: "I seem to have #(marked) the wrong content, why is it different from yours?" ?"

;

;"It's Worth It" is Liu Jiayin's third feature film, but she said, "To a certain extent, this is my debut film." This film is her first time working with professional actors and a filming team, which requires a lot of communication work. The introverted Liu Jiayin needs to take a brand new step.

;

;;

;

;In 2023, director Liu Jiayin released her new feature film "Worth It" after a lapse of fourteen years. ;(Photo provided by the interviewee);

;

;Liu Jiayin is a teacher in the Literature Department of Beijing Film Academy. In her 17 years of teaching, she has often been criticized by her colleagues. Ask the same question as the students: "When will you make a movie again?"

;

;To a certain extent, Liu Jiayin can be regarded as famous at a young age. In her first year of graduate school, at just 24 years old, she made her debut with the feature film "Cowhide" shot on DV. "Won an important award in the Youth Forum section of the Berlin Film Festival. At the age of 28, she was shortlisted for the Cannes Film Festival Directors' Fortnight for "Cowhide 2" and became a young director of great concern to the international film community. But for the next fourteen years, due to various reasons, she had no new films released.

;

;"People around me are asking why I stopped filming? The motivation brought by pressure is huge." Liu Jiayin said.

;

;In the first two movies, Liu Jiayin took care of almost all the affairs of the crew by herself. She was the director, screenwriter and photographer, as well as the producer and starring role. "It was the era of DV, and I am particularly grateful to this period. I was definitely a beneficiary of it. This equipment was very suitable for my personality of 'working alone'." Liu Jiayin recalled.

;

;In 2019, Liu Jiayin began to officially write the script of "It's a Worth It". The final version was more than 60,000 words long, which is more than twice the length of ordinary scripts. Liu Jiayin also wrote a novel of more than 100,000 words for the characters in the script, describing the life of the novel's protagonist Wen Shan in more detail.

;

;The original title of "It's Worth It" was "Listening", not only because Wen Shan's work in the film requires listening to complete, but also because of Liu Jiayin's insights in life, "Listening is not hearing. It’s about understanding the other person and learning to think from the other person’s perspective.”

;

;Wen Shan, the protagonist of "It's Worth It", is a frustrated screenwriter. He gave up his original profession because he couldn't write the stories that Party A needed, and accidentally became a eulogy writer. . This new career requires him to learn to listen to other people's stories and restore the emotions of the deceased to the deceased, and his own life has also turned around.

;

;Every time he receives an order, Wenshan will visit the relatives and friends of the deceased and take a lot of notes to learn as much as possible about the deceased. He interviewed his sister who felt sorry for her brother who always acted as a "good guy" and could not let go of him until his death; he met a son who was busy with work and neglected to communicate with his old father when he was still alive, so he could only regret it for the rest of his life; he also got to know the man who had traveled thousands of miles from Gansu to A persistent girl in Beijing who explores the true state of deceased netizens... Among Wenshan's many clients, there is also Aunt Fang, a cancer patient who booked a eulogy for herself early. After learning that she had cancer, she chose to actively "fight towards death" born".

;

;In this job, Wenshan healed his clients and himself. Starring Hu Ge told Southern Weekend reporters that Wen Shan's work is to influence others, "nourishing the living with the dead" and allowing the living to feel the meaning of life.

;

;At the end of the film, Wenshan finally had the courage to face his past failures, and he could face the script that he could not finish no matter what, and write characters he believed in. "The most important thing is that life recognizes Wen Shan." Liu Jiayin said.

;

;In June 2023, the 25th Shanghai International Film Festival awarded the Best Director Award to Liu Jiayin, and she was once again recognized by the Class A film festival. In September, "It's Worth It" was officially released, which was Liu Jiayin's first movie to be released in public. After the movie was released, her Weibo really played a "listening" role. She received hundreds of private messages from viewers. People shared their feelings about watching the movie with the director in text, pouring out their deepest feelings to their relatives and friends. emotions.

;

;;

;

;In the process of directing a new film, listening and cooperation have taken on a new meaning for Liu Jiayin (second from right). ;(Photo provided by interviewee);

;

;A pair of elderly sisters in their seventies, suffering from lung cancer and breast cancer respectively, They actively treated each other and encouraged each other, while accompanying their 95-year-old mother until her old age. After watching "It's Worth It" four times, my sister wrote in a private message: "We wrote eulogies for our mother, but we were shy to express our love in front of her; just like Wen Shan, when he was down and out, he was confused and inferior, and he struggled to give up... Your story allows us to see ourselves.”

;

;A young girl shared the story of her mother who died after eight years of suffering from cancer. "It would be great if my mother could leave the traces of her short life on paper. I am also a filmmaker. I hope that one day I can have my mother's story well recorded..."

;

;Some of the people who shared regretted being too rebellious when their grandma was alive, some did not catch up with their relatives for the last time, and some opened up their hearts with their families because of this movie... These stories flew into Liu Jiayin's mailbox one after another, and she would Try to reply one by one during work breaks. "These strangers gave me a lot of encouragement. This is the most meaningful part of the movie." Liu Jiayin said.

;

;“Very specific fears” bring huge creative motivation

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;When you first made a movie, you chose one person to do everything. Isn’t this a very common approach? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;If it were the kind of movie machine that I used to have, I might not be able to afford it, nor would I know how to cooperate with others. I was using a DV player. At that time, there were still many doubts about using such a special method to shoot movies. So I chose not to listen, thinking that I could just make it myself. I grew up slowly after the age of 30 and began to learn how to communicate. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The earliest name of "It's Worth It" is "Listen", how do you understand this name? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;After working, I gradually discovered that in life we ​​really need to listen. Listening is not about hearing, but about truly understanding the other person. Not only have I been misunderstood by others in my life, but I have also misunderstood others. After something like this happens again and again, you need to constantly correct your views on others, and you need to listen to them. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Many people may be concerned about the aftermath of "Niuhide" , why did it take fourteen years to make a movie, and why is this "A Journey Well Worth It"? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;I am not a person who does things very quickly. I have my own rhythm, and I may not have waited for the story I particularly wanted to tell. The things I encounter every day in my daily life are very specific, and there are also some rewards and fun, so I have a lot of "excuses" not to create. ;

;

;Later, the prototype of the character Wen Shan came into being, and it took several years. The character didn't have a name at the time, but I felt that he often appeared in my life, even in my room, and I would always think of him, so I gave him a name and determined to write his story.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Your previous two movies are very close to your own life Yes, you and your family are directly on the scene. "It's a Worth It" is a completely fictional film. What is its relationship with your own life? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;The previous creations were quite experimental, and "Worthless Journey" is different in every aspect. To a certain extent, it is My debut novel. But this movie still has a lot to do with my personal experience. It is a summary of my life over the past ten years, and everything I want to say is in it. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Looking back over the past ten years, do you think you What are the changes? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin: ;;When I was filming "Cowhide", I was young, so I just gritted my teeth and made the film. Now my mentality is more complicated and requires greater drive. will be more rational. ;

;

;I haven’t made a movie for a long time, and there is a high probability that I will never make another one, but I almost never stopped thinking about it. As I get older, I realize that time is limited, and I am afraid of it. If I don’t do something, I can predict what will happen in the future. This is a very specific fear, and it brings great motivation.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;From 2006 to the present, you have been a university teacher for seventeen years. What impact has your teaching experience had on you? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;If I want to teach my class well, I must understand my students. This process is not particularly easy for me, especially since I am very bad at interacting with people. Every time I open the door to meet new students in the new semester, I need to do some mental construction. But what I teach is how to write stories. You must know why students write such things. You can't just say whether it is good or not. You need to understand them through stories. After slowly adjusting, I roughly knew how to express myself and take care of every student as much as possible. ;

;

;"You can find the answer by living seriously"

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Wenshan needs to come into contact with all kinds of people in his work. Several of his customers appear in the movie, and they all have their own stories. Do these characters have life prototypes? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin: ;;There is no prototype. It mainly comes from daily observation of life and the screenwriter’s skills. A screenwriter should write in a way that makes people believe. In fact, I don’t have any creative skills, I just live seriously. The client's story is different in age, relationship with deceased relatives and friends, and understanding of emotions. It is similar to the situations we encounter in life. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Wen Shan can’t be a good screenwriter, what do you think? Where is the problem stuck? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;Human beings have a natural part, coupled with their experiences from childhood to adulthood, they have shaped us together and made us what we are today. look. I think Wen Shan encountered too many rejections in his previous work as a screenwriter. He was thought that the things he wrote were too ordinary, not enough for this, not enough for that. In short, the characters he wrote were "not worthy" of being the protagonists. After Wen Shan was denied again and again, he gradually began to doubt himself. Especially when you still can't pay the rent a few years after graduation and have to ask your parents for rent, it's a very difficult feeling. This sense of failure not only denies work, but also denies values. Do you think, "Is the way I look at life wrong?" ;

;

;I think Wenshan has not tried to defend himself, but his voice is too soft. In this case, a person's personality will also change. But to a certain extent, a screenwriter who fails to defend his story is failing to defend himself.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Do you think life finally recognized Wen Shan? What does it look like specifically? Recognition? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin: ;;After writing the eulogy, he found that what he had been denied before found answers in life. We can be affected by some small things, and we can also establish real connections with other people. These people are either very dramatic people in the script, or ordinary people who are inconspicuous, but they are very important to the people around them and are important to them. They themselves are also important. ;

;

;After this, Wen Shan will continue to write stories without any obstacles in his heart. We are often like this, always troubled by some invisible and intangible things, but I am convinced that we can find the answer as long as we live seriously.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What do you hope the audience will see through this movie? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin:;;For most people, it is much easier to deny themselves than to affirm themselves. This may be the life of adults. But people still have to care about themselves in the end. "It's Worth It" tells the story of Wen Shan's process of starting to care about himself. He realized that his feelings and things he did were important. This may also be the reason why many viewers left me messages saying they saw themselves in the movie. Those who are completely indifferent after watching this movie are the lucky ones, because no one in this movie really succeeds. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The appearance of "It's Worth It" can Does it solve some of your previous life confusions to a certain extent? ;

;

;;Liu Jiayin: ;;I think it was because I solved these confusions that I came up with this movie. In other words, after knowing yourself, you must accept yourself. ;

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 17:25:03 +0800 担心被称“普信”，不敢接触异性：一位大学老师对男生女生的观察http://www.infzm.com/contents/260410
;;2023-11-11 16:00:00;
;

;On a recent Friday, at 2:30 in the afternoon, I parked my car in the parking lot of Guangzhou University and found that the playground There were two boys playing basketball, and they came to play so early. My curiosity drove me to get closer. I pitched and chatted with them. They are freshmen from the School of Foreign Languages. They are not only classmates, but also fellow Zhanjiang fellows. It happened that there were no classes or homework on Friday afternoon, so we were bored, so we met to play basketball.

;

;Men and women are clearly differentiated

;

;As I walked, I asked how many people were in their class. They told me that there were 34 girls and 5 boys.

;

;"Why didn't you think about asking the female classmates in the class to go out for fun?" I asked casually.

;

;They were quite surprised by my suggestion: "Teacher, I don't know any of the girls in the class." "Teacher, I know two girls in our class, but they asked me to date them. This is absolutely impossible."

;

;"There are 34 girls, how many people have you added to WeChat?" I continued to ask.

;

;“I added 5 people, but I don’t have much contact with them.” Classmate A said.

;

;"Three, and they are all cadres in the class, but I only contact them when something happens." Classmate B replied to me.

;

;"You are a freshman now. You should have a lot of courses, and there should be many opportunities to take classes together." I continued to ask.

;

;"Yes, we have classes together almost every day. The problem is that although we are in the same classroom, boys sit with boys and girls sit with girls. In class, they mainly listen to the teacher's lectures; after class, they disperse separately. , there is little communication and interaction with each other." Student A said.

;

;"Both boys and girls, everyone deliberately keeps their distance. Everyone agrees that as soon as they enter the classroom, boys and girls will sit separately." Classmate B added.

;

;Theoretically, college students should have relatively free control of their time. Their physical and mental development has matured, and their need for interaction with the opposite sex is relatively strong. It is normal for them to date and become friends with the opposite sex, but the reality is not in this way.

;

;Although classmates in the same class can meet every day and have many contact opportunities, having contact opportunities does not necessarily mean that substantial familiarity, understanding and understanding will occur in real life. Where is "Geng"?

;

;Seeing the confusion on my face, classmate B told me the whole story, "Teacher, have you heard of some hot words on the Internet, such as 'licking the dog', 'lowering the head' and 'Pu Xin'?" ”

;

;After his explanation, I realized that among boys and girls, the one who takes the initiative to add the other party’s WeChat account or asks for the other party’s contact information will be considered by a small number of members of the opposite sex to be a “dog licker” and a “lower” person. This situation is relatively common for boys who take the initiative. In other words, when a boy takes the initiative to add a friend to a girl he is interested in or finds interesting, some girls will think this is a strange thing and ask, "What do you want to do?" "What are your intentions?" "Do you want to pursue her?" Me?" If the boy is not the right person for the girl, the girl will think that the boy is "general trustworthy", which means "ordinary but confident". The problem is that some girls may not think this way, but in order to avoid girls thinking this way, boys do not want to be misunderstood and bear the stigmatized label of "normal men", so they would rather or simply not be active or take the initiative to avoid embarrassment, even in the face of The girl you are most attracted to or the girl you like the most.

;

;"Does the teacher know about the 'campus wall'?" Classmate A asked me.

;

;Of course I don’t know. He explained to me this way: "It is a public platform for students to publish information. It seems that every university has it. For example, once I join someone else and I am rejected, they will remove me. If I post screenshots of others on the 'campus wall', then all the students in the school will know about me, and I will be polite and sweep the floor in school, unable to hold my head up."

;

;"I can't control the other person's thinking, thoughts and actions. , I am even more unable to face and avoid this kind of risk, so I will not take the initiative to get close to the opposite sex." Classmate B said helplessly.

;

;Invisible Wall

;

;This reminds me of: A year ago, I played ball with several boys from my senior graduating class. They told me that after four years, they could not recognize any of them. Students in the same class may not be able to name their classmates. In their eyes, students of the opposite sex in the same class or major are just "classmates" rather than "friends", "close friends" or "besties".

;

;According to my observation, a basic feeling is that the current friendship or friendship between college students in the same major or class, especially between people of the opposite sex, is very weak. They are either busy or idle, and they are busy. Even if they may have a crush on a classmate of the opposite sex, they will never take the initiative or actively express their needs or wishes to make friends or interact with each other. In other words, after entering college, an "invisible heart wall" suddenly appears between boys and girls. This wall imprisons boys and girls, and no one wants to take the initiative to tear down this wall.

;

;Of course, it was high school before entering college. The relationship between classmates in high school was generally very good. They got along with each other day and night, discussed and solved problems together, had fun and decompressed together. The boys handed ambiguous notes to the girls they liked, and the girls Look at the boy you like a few more times, meet at a corner of the school gate next night during self-study, and arrange to go home together. When you are excited, hold each other's hand and give him warmth, strength or encouragement. How normal is this?

;

;My college years

;

;I can’t help but think of my college career, which was from 1997 to 2001. In the first class in the first week after the military training, the head teacher spent two whole classes asking each student to come up to the podium and introduce themselves. Then everyone went to a restaurant at the school gate to have lunch together, and they quickly became familiar with each other. . Boys and girls meet together for morning reading, breakfast, and class; after dinner, everyone has evening self-study together. After self-study, they play badminton for an hour on a wide road in the school.

;

;Public displays of love were also extremely common at that time. When it comes to the person of the opposite sex they like, a generous and cheerful person will express their feelings directly, "Can I ask you to watch a movie?"; a shy and reserved person will use an intermediary to act as a matchmaker and express their intention to date through a small note or letter. If two people have dinner together, watch a movie (usually an all-night movie), and then hold hands, it basically declares that the "intimate male-female relationship" has been basically established.

;

;In other words, it is normal to express this emotion or affection to someone you like or like. I remember clearly that there were 42 people in our class, 22 boys and 20 girls. When I graduated as a senior, there were as many as 5 couples.

;

;Concerned about the values ​​​​and true psychology of contemporary college students

;

;Boys today are generally not interested in love, don’t they want to know and understand girls? Or on the contrary, are girls today generally not interested in falling in love and not wanting to get to know and understand boys? I feel neither. Faced with the overall environment of high employment pressure, some people have been nervous since their freshman year and are busy with postgraduate entrance examinations, public entrance examinations, College English Level 4 and 6, driver's licenses, teacher qualification certificates, etc. However, in addition to "many things to do", they When people still feel lonely or lonely in their hearts, they also long to meet or have a beautiful love. The problem is that no one wants to be considered a "dog-licking tribe", "Xiatou tribe" or "Puxin tribe", and no one wants to take the initiative Go out and get to know the opposite sex.

;

;Contemporary college students are relatively unfamiliar with their classmates, so who are they relatively familiar with? It is understood that compared to students taking public courses or professional courses, it is easier for them to get acquainted with people who have the same or similar interests or hobbies. For example, the relationship between classmates within hip-hop clubs, literary clubs, basketball clubs, opera clubs, etc. should be close to classmates who have taken the same professional course. The reason is that various clubs are more in line with the interests or hobbies of students. This is what they like or like to do in their hearts. Everyone communicates and learns skills together, and closely cooperates and collaborates together, which can often brew the seeds of emotion. And in In professional courses, the course itself may be relatively difficult, and most students are not very interested in discussing or communicating together, so the establishment of close relationships naturally takes a long time. From a spatial perspective, professional classrooms are formal, formal and serious spaces, while various clubs are informal, informal and leisure spaces. The latter make people relatively relaxed, relaxed and natural. This is the informal space. effect.

;

;Let college students feel more relaxed and light, make them feel physically and mentally happy, let them dare and have the courage to do the "duty things" that suit their age group, let the friendship between classmates return to innocence and depth, and let the conversation Talking about love has become a matter of course, which is what the new atmosphere of contemporary college students should mean.

;

;In order to achieve the above goals, I believe that relevant parties should pay more attention to the values ​​​​and true psychology and mentality of contemporary college students. Each university has set up public required courses on the psychology of college students to encourage and advocate the construction of an open An inclusive and harmonious relationship between men and women breaks down all kinds of conceptual barriers and obstacles that create gender opposition and hostility. In terms of course learning, teachers may wish to encourage students to conduct group discussions, and suggest that men and women be paired into groups to create a good atmosphere for heterosexual discussions.

;

;In addition, relevant parties should find breakthroughs in extracurricular time, fill students' extracurricular time with as many public activities as possible, and create opportunities for male and female students to contact, understand and understand each other, such as organizing students to carry out Campus tours, city tours, outings, autumn outings, weekend hikes or dinner parties, etc.

;

;(The author is a professor at the Department of Sociology, Guangzhou University)

;Time

;

;In 2020, director Zhang Lu returned to Beijing from South Korea and was quarantined in a hotel in Guangzhou for two weeks in accordance with the COVID-19 prevention and control policy at the time. He wrote a script and sent it to Xin Baiqing, saying that the protagonist Gu Wentong was written for him.

;

;Gu Wentong is from Beijing. He is divorced. His daughter is fostered at his sister’s house. He lives in the old house left by his mother. He has an affair with a young girl and then separates. His best friend as a boy is in a foreign country. suicide. This person who once wrote poetry now makes a living by writing articles about food. He wanders the streets and alleys of Beijing, lonely, and has a sense of drifting that cannot be stabilized.

;

;Actor Xin Baiqing previously collaborated with Zhang Lu in "The Long Confession" (2021) - the brothers Lichun and Lidong went to Japan from Beijing to find Yanagawa, a girl with whom they had a bond when they were young. Having something on your mind. Xin Baiqing plays Li Chun, who already has a family. He goes to a foreign country and hides his loneliness and discomfort in a nonchalant way. He said, "Director Zhang Lu prefers to write about people who have a sense of wandering and loneliness."

;

;Xin Baiqing let Zhang Lu see this feeling at a certain moment when Xin Baiqing was resting or lost in thought on the set.

;

;Gu Wentong lives next to the White Tower, and Xin Baiqing also grew up in Beijing. Zhang Lu once said that Xin Baiqing has the "not anxiousness" of an old Beijinger. People who are not in a hurry seem to be taking things too slowly, have heavier traces of time on their bodies, and have a closer relationship with the past than those who keep running forward.

;

;Gu Wentong in "The Light of the White Tower" looks like a man trapped in time. He wears lazy cloth shoes, only a ginger corduroy jacket and a floppy backpack. Most of the time Walking, occasionally taking the bus, and eating braised food that "only people over fifty years old miss" are separated from everything that is happening at the moment, and I am used to saying sorry to everyone.

;

;"Why do I look at such a person more often?" Zhang Lu said in an interview with "Watching Movies", "Because for this kind of person, the past time is still there, and the present time is still there. Subtle changes have occurred, and two things from time are squeezing on him."

;

;For Gu Wentong, the past time and the present state are both related to the missing father: the five-year-old In 2006, my father was accused of molesting a woman on the bus and my mother kicked him out of the house. When he reached middle age, he suddenly received news that his father's "hooligan crime" was an unjust case. For so many years, his father had been watching him from a distance.

;

;The scene of reconciliation between father and son was brief. The two danced a ballroom dance in a simple room accompanied by DVD footage from the last century.

;

;Two grown men dancing together is not a Chinese way of expressing emotions, let alone Xin Baiqing's. He asked Zhang Lu, how to dance? Zhang Lu said that he can dance when the time comes. He asked Tian Zhuangzhuang, who played the father, that he could understand all the scenes in the script and could imagine the final appearance, but the dancing scene was weird. Tian Zhuangzhuang also said that there will be a solution on that day.

;

;When that day came, Xin Baiqing said one line first: Dad, stand up. The two of them jumped stiffly a few times. Xin Baiqing said to Tian Zhuangzhuang, Dad, the blood vessels in your hands are like earthworms - this is what his daughter said to Gu Wentong before.

;

;Tian Zhuangzhuang glanced at his hand, and then put his hand on Xin Baiqing's shoulder. Dancing comes naturally.

;

;That’s right, Xin Baiqing sighed. "With this one action, my father's emotions for so many years fell into his hands and onto my shoulders. This action is small, but it contains too much content." He thought, "When you go straight to the result and the goal, When you are doing this, you will wonder why it is so difficult? But forget about the result and purpose, and when you enjoy the process and express it, the results will appear naturally."

;

;;

;

;Movie "The Light of the White Tower" Stills ;;

;

;People's Insurance Drama

;

;On October 27, 2023, "The Light of the White Tower" will be released. The film was shortlisted for the main competition of the 73rd Berlin Film Festival at the beginning of the year. In April, director Zhang Lu attended the "Light of the White Tower" post-screening event at the Beijing Film Festival and commented, "Xin Baiqing's performance is self-evident. It's easy to win awards for hard-working performances. Xin Baiqing deserves the award."< /p>;

;In terms of fame, Xin Baiqing may not be a first-line star actor. In some years, he did not have many film and television works. But in the movie "Legend of the Demon Cat" (2017), in just a few scenes, the audience was completely attracted by his performance as Li Bai.

;

;He only has one scene in the script: Gao Lishi carries Li Bai to the Banquet of Bliss. Li Bai was drunk and composed a poem, "The clouds want the clothes and the flowers want the face." Drunkness is the keynote. Xin Baiqing thought, does he really want to act drunk? "My understanding of Li Bai is that it was a period when Li Bai was particularly sober, because all his illusions about his official career had been shattered. Everyone was praising him for being a high official. He knew very well that it was over." To have Drunk state, but you must be sober and cannot act drunk.

;

;On the set, director Chen Kaige said that there would be no need to walk in the scene later, and he would just shoot it directly. Great, Xin Baiqing later said, "I am willing to collide with the most vivid things."

;

;The first shot was passed in one go. When he got to the monitor, Chen Kaige first said something off-topic, "We have to cooperate in the future"; then he showed Xin Baiqing the monitor: Xin Baiqing sat up, stretched out, and rubbed against the golden tortoise, and then asked Concubine Yang Youyou ,who are you?

;

;Chen Kaige said, this is Li Bai.

;

;TV drama viewers may have known Xin Baiqing through "Happiness is Like a Flower" (2005) in the early years or "Da Qin Fu" (2020) in recent years. The role that really makes him remembered is Zhou Bingyi in the period drama "Human World" (2022) - the eldest brother in an ordinary family in Northeast China: sent to the countryside as an educated youth, admitted to Peking University, and later became an official with outstanding contributions during the reform and opening up period. The shadow of many people in special times.

;

;Screenwriter Wang Haiyu received an invitation to adapt and read Liang Xiaosheng’s original novel. He felt that the description of Zhou Bingyi was relatively thin, such as the process of demolishing the "Guangzi Film" in the shantytown where he grew up after he took over the government. Passed a few pens. In Wang Hailu’s story, his younger brother Zhou Bingkun represents the family (;the grassroots people;), and his older brother Zhou Bingyi represents the country (;Government officials;) are the backbone. So she put a lot of effort into writing the scene after Zhou Bingyi became a leading cadre. "If I have to say it, the first half of this play is Zhou Bingkun's home court, and the second half is Zhou Bingyi's home court," she said.

;

;About halfway through the broadcast of "Human World", Wang Hailu and Xin Baiqing met at an event. Zhou Bingyi's highlight hasn't been aired yet. Wang Haiyuan doesn't know what Xin Baiqing can do. The two parties only exchanged a few polite words. She seemed to have heard Xin Baiqing say, "This script is very literary." She thought this was just a polite comment. .

;

;After watching the complete drama, Wang Hailu regretted not chatting more with Xin Baiqing, "This is such a good actor."

;

;"A brief example: watching the demolition of shantytowns in the drama Before that scene, I was a little nervous. I gave Zhou Bingyi a few thousand words of lines for that scene. When the plot came to that point, I could only write it like this. I thought the director might have a way to reduce the difficulty of performing this scene during filming. ——I didn’t dare to expect the actor to fulfill his wish. At that time, I had the impression that Xin Baiqing was a niche actor in literary films. ——Unexpectedly, the ten-minute scene was filmed in one shot. Xin Baiqing used his His understanding of the characters, his talent in temperament, and his line skills have successfully endowed him with the real nobility that a ruler should have."

;

;More than a year has passed since the premiere of "Human World", and Zhou Bingyi was demolished in a shanty town. Clips of handling disputes on the spot and explaining policies to neighborhood friends whom he has known since childhood are still circulated on self-media and have become classic examples of both performance and speech.王海鸰写小说出身，后来调入总政话剧团做戏剧，她说，“彼时常听前辈老师们说，戏保人，人保戏。周秉义这个角色的成功，当属人保戏。”

;

;;

;

;一个人

;

;《人世间》之后，辛柏青接到大量官员类角色。但他不想被类型化，新鲜的角色才能激起他的好奇心。他拍了纪录片导演徐童的首部剧情片《三个十年》，演反角闫永刚，和演警察贾国志的段奕宏搭戏。在春风得意的年代，闫永刚于一次追捕行动中打伤警察贾国志，贾没死，闫也没被捕，结了血仇，但是生出了棋逢敌手的惺惺相惜。

;

;徐童在自己的原著小说《珍宝岛》里是这样写官员子弟闫永刚的：出手黑，人白净，带着一股阴气。

;

;徐童和辛柏青一起去作家阿城家讨论《珍宝岛》的改编，那是他第一次见辛柏青，刚停车下来，看到后面辛柏青开着一辆SUV也到了，一个人，没有团队，没有助理。 “当时我就觉得很舒服，他是很自然的、一个人的状态。没有演艺圈的习气，或者说演员的做派。”

;

;在阿城家见过面之后，阿城跟徐童说，你注意看，柏青含胸。

;

;徐童后来仔细观察，辛柏青一点儿也不含胸，一米八几，挺直溜个人。徐童问辛柏青，一直就是这个形体？辛柏青说是，几十年一直这样，一点儿没胖，也一点儿没瘦。

;

;徐童明白了，阿城指的并不是形体，而是辛柏青给人一种含胸的印象。 “因为他的消瘦气质，他身上的含蓄。”类似的，徐童发现辛柏青有一种特殊的眼神，“他看事物看东西，不是那种眼睛放光，直接看，而是感觉好像隔着一层东西，光往回收，含在里面。”

;

;意识到这两点，再看辛柏青塑造的角色，徐童觉得，“他的表达是适度的，同时也是饱满的，饱满是说他背后的东西是饱满的。”陈凯歌对辛柏青有类似的评价，他说辛柏青“吃得很深，吐得很少”。

;

;2022年春天，《三个十年》在陕西开机。辛柏青答应徐童提前进组，推掉了别的安排。 “他说过完春节之后，我就溜达过去了。”徐童回忆，“至今回想起来我们那一段时间的工作，我都觉得他不是一个演员，他没有把我们这个合作当成一个项目，他就是创作一个人物。熟悉环境，进入空间，然后进到这个人物当中去。”

;

;开机前有剧本围读，大家谈得不多，徐童说，辛柏青和段奕宏已经把人物翻来覆去吃透，再谈多，反而影响现场的即兴感。他用“非常刺激，又非常惊喜”形容两位演员的表演。

;

;虽然合作愉快，但徐童和辛柏青在那部戏之后的交往并不多。部分原因是徐童有意为之，“我需要跟演员保持一个距离，是为了产生一种陌生感，私交多了会影响未来对人物的想象力。”

;

;他觉得辛柏青更懂这个道理，所以在角色之外很少露面，“如果观众对你这张脸太熟悉了，当你再去塑造一个人物的时候，那个人物的可信度就会降低，或者说冲击感就会降低。”好演员需要保持相当程度的孤独状态。

;

;;

;

;“三板斧”

;

;我们找到的辛柏青的合作伙伴都很愿意谈论他的表演，但是要和他本人聊表演并不容易，像张律说的，他是含着的；或者像徐童说的，他是往回收的。

;

;比起细致地讲述心路历程，他更愿意这样总结：

;

;“我的工作方法就是尽量把文学描述变为可视化的形象。第一步，我的形象从哪而来？他是什么样子的，大概什么发型，穿什么衣服，戴不戴眼镜，他走路的姿势，他说话的方式，他有没有习惯动作，这其实都是上学的时候学的最基础的。然后，剧本的一些背景，剧本没有写的，但是我要给他丰富的一些情感关系，或者是一些经历，自己去更多地为这个人物想象更深的一个维度。这样演出来以后这个人物就没有那么片面和单一化，观众就会觉得他可能有更多的侧面和立体。”

;

;“这演员的基本功是观察生活，没别的技巧，没有什么新的内容，全是三板斧，但是这三板斧你要扎扎实实地做好，那就是演员武装到自己的牙齿。”

;

;就是靠着这三板斧，他一次次离开自己的舒适区，迎接新角色的挑战。 “我接戏只考虑我感不感兴趣，而不会考虑我能不能掌控。我看到一个新角色，我掌控不了，就不演了，永远没有进步。”

;

;乍一看，《漫长的告白》中的立春和辛柏青一点都不像。制片人徐佳含回忆，剧组最早定下的演员是张鲁一，演弟弟立冬，一个有点执拗的罹患癌症的文艺中年。他们问张鲁一，你给自己找个哥哥，看谁合适？哥哥立春有点像立冬的反面，世俗、外放。

;

;张鲁一回答：辛柏青。他觉得辛柏青有点“闷骚的感觉”。

;

;于是有了辛柏青和导演张律的第一次合作。一场戏，在日本的民宿，立春和年少的恋人柳川相对而坐，说话，辛柏青眼泪唰地流下来，“那是在诉说，在悔悟。那种表现我觉得特别清晰。”

;

;张律喊咔，再来一条，让辛柏青冲着墙说台词。 “我当时就想，刚刚那个不好吗？当然我没跟导演探讨，既然已经有表达强烈一点的了，我就来一遍导演说的。”下一条，辛柏青背对镜头，喃喃自语。

;

;成片里，张律用了后一条。辛柏青想，也对，立春也许是对柳川有感情，也许只是为了寻找自我来到此地，“而我那种表演把所有的可能性局限在了一种，反而让路子更窄了。”

;

;辛柏青迅速理解了张律的风格，他说，看张律的电影像读诗，没有标准答案。 2020年底，我采访张律时，他确实说，电影应当像诗。

;

;凭借立春这个角色，辛柏青获得了中国电影金鸡奖最佳男配角奖。

;

;到《白塔之光》，两人已经非常默契，没有过多的讨论。张律会问他，演得舒服吗？挺舒服的。那就行了，拍下一个。

;

;“所谓的舒服（就是），我觉得都对了。这场戏没有'个个楞楞'的，没有那种很难受的、过不去的动作、行为、语气。是波澜不惊的、静水深流的表达方式，而不是哪个音符蹦出来了，变得强烈了；哪个音符又变得低沉了。可能用在这个电影里，舒服的感觉是这个样子的。”辛柏青说。

;

;背负着时代和家庭的不如意，在暧昧的两性关系和戏剧化的父子关系里，谷文通这个角色可演的地方很多。但辛柏青知道张律要的是不外化的表演，甚至是不演。

;

;“他就经常说，生活当中人是多面化的，你也许上一秒还在挺高兴地说一件事，下一秒可能就陷入到一种很自我的情绪里边了，不知道为什么。人也会经常跑神，也会说一些不着边际的话，这都是真实的生活状态。”

;

;“这就对表演者提了更高的要求，不演，需要特别强大的内心定力，要不然会觉得，我没演，是不是不对？但恰恰是我不怀疑自己、内心特别笃定的时候，可能生出来另外一种无法言说的状态。观众会捕捉到。不演反而可能内心需要更充实，这种充实不是说目的性更充实，而是你的过往人生、阅历，你的气质、思想内涵在那一瞬间，都会让人能够感受得到。”

;

;2023年4月29日，北影节闭幕式暨颁奖典礼举行，如张律所说，辛柏青果真拿了奖。他凭借《白塔之光》获得“天坛奖”最佳男主角。这是他拿到的第一个影帝。

;

;;

;

;话剧《狂飙》剧照;（受访者提供/图）;

;

;游戏感

;

;影视角色之外，辛柏青一直是国家话剧院的演员。第一部大剧场戏是导演田沁鑫的《狂飙》（2001），他演主角田汉，戏里有打破第四堵墙的自述，有和表妹、和妻子、和红颜的情感，还有若干戏中戏，比如田汉翻译的《莎乐美》中的叙利亚少年、写的剧本里的关汉卿，都由辛柏青演。后来在《红玫瑰与白玫瑰》（2007）中，他演个全上海都知道的“柳下惠”。 《四世同堂》（2010）里，他演胡同里汲汲于名利、向日本人求官的冠晓荷——拿了话剧金狮奖表演奖。到《青蛇》（2013），他演法海，有人性，有神性。 2023年他还在排田沁鑫的新戏《苏堤春晓》，演苏轼。

;

;辛柏青记得多次合作的导演田沁鑫的一句话：戏剧和影视最大的不同，或说戏剧最大的魅力在于，可装扮性更强。影视剧不会找辛柏青的，田沁鑫会找。 “去装扮这个角色，就特别有游戏感，这一下让我豁然开朗。这件事变成了一件好玩的事儿，不是说我要苦大仇深地去塑造一个什么，戏比天大，这么大一个枷锁给你套上，不是的。”

;

;在舞台上二十多年，辛柏青的角色不算多，两只手数得过来，现在回看，每一个角色的故事他都还能想得起来。与影视相比，戏剧离名利远，辛柏青自己有时候也想为什么一直没有离开戏剧呢？

;

;“名利可能就是某一瞬间，我这戏播火了真好，被这么多人认可了，很享受，但很快就会过去。但是演话剧，在排练场里天天连滚带爬地排练，这种简单的快乐太难得了。岁数越大，面临的事、社会环境、关系也越来越复杂，（演话剧）这事儿就是不复杂。我能回到简单的地方，找到小的时候的状态就会特别快乐。”辛柏青说。

;

;“他身上有一种非常干净的气质。这份干净是很难得的。”田沁鑫说过，在排练场，她有时会突然被辛柏青感动。

;

;2017年，新版《狂飙》上演，辛柏青作为观众去看，觉得年轻一代演员比自己当年演得好。 “我年轻的时候有点没心没肺，每天就是乐呵、傻玩，并不过脑子，事儿不往心里装。因为装多了以后挺痛苦的，你知道吗？”

;

;“但是没办法，生活就硬往怀里塞，这么多年也塞了不少了。”

;

;生活给他塞了什么？

;

;“柴米油盐，都往里装。具体你真的说不出来。这就是活着，过日子。”

;

;辛柏青演的那版《狂飙》，有一段，田汉在东京看戏，一段自白，大意是，找到了自己热爱的志业，像是行星找到了轨道一般：“小时候我就有些迷障，我大概是无法悟道了。我只热爱我要的颜色，我会听凭它牵引出一条轨道，引我自由公转。”

;

;我说出这段台词，问辛柏青在年轻时是否很有共鸣，他否认了。

;

;“小的时候真的不知道这是什么意思，只是把这词念出来了，为赋新词强说愁的一种状态。什么人生，什么牵引，什么我的颜色，到底我要什么，我不知道。现在到了这个岁数了全都知道了，反而也可以不用说这样的话了，一切感悟都在，却道天凉好个秋了。”

;

;通过作品，很难寻觅到他在表演上爬坡的轨迹。他也没有给出所谓的“开窍时刻”。

;

;“我明白你的问题，但是没有一个具体节点。因为生活本身没有节点，我的生活四平八稳的，但是四平八稳的生活，愿不愿意去用心体会？用心体会了，年龄、岁月带给人的就会潜移默化、一点点积淀。”

;

;他只说，如果现在再演田汉，应该是不一样了。

;

;钝

;

;2008年，导演姜伟拍《潜伏》，最先考虑的是请辛柏青和朱媛媛两口子出演余则成和翠平，他觉得辛柏青身上有文人气。不巧赶上朱媛媛怀孕，姜伟说辛柏青一个人去也可以，辛柏青为了陪产也没去。

;

;《潜伏》播出之后，成了现象级电视剧，全国各地拿奖。辛柏青有遗憾，但不后悔。与喜爱的角色擦肩而过，这不是唯一一次。

;

;曾经辛柏青最想演的角色是浮士德。在歌德的戏剧《浮士德》里，这位博闻的学者与魔鬼梅菲斯特做交易，出卖自己的灵魂以换取无尽的学识和智慧，甘愿在死后投身地狱。后来真的有人来找他演《浮士德》的时候，他拒绝了。

;

;“为什么这个机会到我手边的时候，我又不去演了呢，我纠结了好长时间，后来发现我想演的不是歌德的浮士德。”他无法用只言片语解释自己想演的浮士德是什么，但是他清楚自己不要什么。

;

;“我给人感觉挺钝的，生活当中给人感觉反正也不大灵光不大聪明的。”辛柏青这样说自己。但他有自己的小世界。特别累的时候，或者坐车赶路，他在网上看别人下四国军棋，有时候看到棋出得太臭，他也说，这看不下去，给关了，过会儿再点进去看看。 “就诸如此类，我自己心里边玩得特别高兴，但是跟别人一沟通起来，又变成了一个特别无聊的人。”

;

;辛柏青喜欢潜水。把生命搁在水底，杂念被迫压缩到最少，氧气含量、潜水深度、方向，都没问题了，终于可以放下心来看一眼海底的时候，他觉得，可能跟到了太空的感觉差不多，心情一下就变得开阔了。

;

;做演员的人都敏感，但是敏感有时候会伤害自己，作为“内向的、不善于表达的人”，辛柏青用这种方式让自己放空。

;

;徐佳含是《漫长的告白》和《白塔之光》的制片人，她说，“柏青老师在现实生活中，跟剧组人员都特别客气，特别融洽。”《漫长的告白》到日本拍摄，辛柏青不懂日语，但是“会尽量适应，不愿意给别人添麻烦”。

;

;“但你总觉得他有点小秘密，恰好在剧本里找到了一个出口。”

;

;1997年，中央戏剧学院表演系1993级本科生临近毕业，排练的间隙，十来个同学跟着老师去蹭饭。走在学校门口的东棉花胡同里，老师问了一句，你们毕了业谁还能坚持演话剧？本来欢快的气氛一下子安静了。那个时候演话剧意味着清贫，谁也没吱声。辛柏青接了一句，“要让我一辈子演话剧我都乐意。”

;

;2023年，辛柏青50岁了，当年的老师有的已经离世。每当排话剧、同学聚会、给老师扫墓，他都会回想起那一幕。

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 15:25:03 +0800 微短剧的“危险”狂飙http://www.infzm.com/contents/260414
;;2023-11-11 14:33:10;
;

;微短剧从各种层面都在狂飙。

;

;从市场规模看，据中文在线援引第三方研究报告数据，2022年短剧全年市场规模在100多亿元，2023年微短剧规模预计突破300亿元。  

;

;从市场供给来看，据广电总局数据，2021年微短剧全年备案数398部，而2022年备案数接近2800部，同比增长600%；2023年3月-8月，全国重点网络微短剧规划备案通过剧目部数，基本在260部以上，且7/8月分别为361部/401部，供给显著增长。

;

;从公司看，中文在线、华策影视、芒果超媒、华谊兄弟、柠萌影视、掌阅科技、长信传媒均在此块加大投入。

;

;但另一头，基于题材“媚俗化”，微短剧市场监管不确定犹存。

;

;11月10日，中文在线报收25.40元/股，跌幅9.19%。此前11月2日到9日，该公司股价短短6个交易日翻倍。

;

;;

;

;;杨蓉主演的微短剧《二十九》在抖音短视频平台正片总播放量超8亿次。图片来源：剧方海报;

;

;“爽点密集”

;

;微短剧最大特点是，回收效率高。

;

;当红微短剧概念股中文在线在投资者交流纪要中表示，短剧特点在于，内容短、集数多，一般是80-100集，每集两分钟以内，剧情带有较强戏剧性，创作内容更加贴合群众需求，故事快反转，剧情爽点密集。更多依托平台广告推流，实现C端客户触达。

;

;在此基础上，微短剧商业验证周期短，回收效率高，主要靠广告投流，投流方只要能够实现首日回收目标，就可以继续优化投流的策略，然后实现高额的ROI回收。一部作品从剧本打磨到拍摄、制作、投流验证， 短时间内就可以完成验证和闭环，资产中转率高。

;

;同时，微短剧制作周期短， 制作成本低，拍摄周期一般在一周以内。  

;

;“不行就换题材，成本太低了。就是打一枪换一炮。”有微短剧创业者对21世纪经济报道记者说。

;

;这让影视基础薄弱的中文在线迅速切入核心赛道。

;

;“公司拥有海量IP优势。目前短剧剧本主要来源于网络小说改编，公司拥有550万种IP，可源源不断提供优质短剧IP改编剧本，长时间赛跑能力突出。”中文在线称。

;

;老牌内容巨头华策影视也在迅速进军这一市场。该公司对外披露，从去年下半年开始研究短剧赛道，今年6月开始建团队， 目前已有6 支队伍，也在引进编剧、制片人，和投流公司合作。 “ 未来的定位是进入微短剧的前五。”华策称。其自认为的优势，显然是制作能力。

;

;客观上，影视巨头布局这一赛道还是有优势。

;

;据柠萌影视披露，2023年初，其打造的微短剧《二十九》在抖音短视频平台的正片总播放量超8亿次，集均播放量超4000万次，相关话题全站总播放量14.5亿次，为抖音短视频微短剧的最高水平。

;

;但当下，微短剧最大特点是“爽感”，对精品制作需求似乎不多。从微短剧创业者到头部影视公司中层，均向21世纪经济报道记者坦承，目前头部影视公司在这一市场优势相对有限。

;

;譬如，《二十九》第二季播出即登上微短剧最热榜TOP1 ，连续5周占据抖音微短剧榜TOP1。可是，热度相对第一季有着明显下滑。

;

;;平台变迁;

;

;大火微短剧背后是，落寞的长视频。

;

;多位影视公司项目负责人均向21世纪经济报道记者感慨，随着平台“降本增效”，挣钱越来越难了。

;

;财报显示，爱奇艺在2022年内容成本为165亿元，同比下降20%。此外，该公司还在力推自制剧。当下，爱奇艺自制内容资产占比持续上升，从2018年的32%升至2022年的63%。爱奇艺还披露，每年上新的重点剧集中，原创内容占比从2018年的20%提升至2022 年的50%以上。以上种种，都挤压了影视项目的利润空间。

;

;此种变化诱因为，长视频脆弱的盈利模式。

;

;今年二季度，爱奇艺营收78.02亿元，同比增长17.2%；归母净利润3.65亿元，去年同期净亏损2.14亿元。但从环比来看，爱奇艺营收处在下滑区间。受《狂飙》推动，一季度，其营收达到83.49亿元，同比增长15%；归母净利润6.181亿元，而上年同期净利润为1.691亿元。

;

;长视频业绩如此波动在于，用户需求走向碎片化以及相对低的变现效率。

;

;据易观千帆数据，2023年9月，爱奇艺月活用户减少至5.6867亿人，腾讯视频月活用户减至4.5017亿人。同期，抖音月活用户减至7.9767亿人，快手月活用户减至5.2236亿人。长短视频差距明显。

;

;另从广告来看，基于更高的变现效率，广告主们纷纷奔向短视频。

;

;香飘飘就对外披露，上半年其冻柠茶销量同比增长547.09%，线上渠道同比增长235%，抖音渠道占比约30%且累计复购率维持高位。劲仔食品也对外表示，线上渠道方面，该公司抖音等新媒体渠道表现亮眼，同比增长约600%。

;

;有头部饮品市场部负责人告诉21世纪经济报道记者，相对爱奇艺等长视频平台，短视频推销效果更直接，变现效率要强得多。 “对长视频变现基本没报太大预期。”他说。另有头部户外运动产品创始人也表达了类似观点。

;

;流量与营收双重夹击下，长视频生态走向存量。

;

;于是，内容公司们也不得不奔向微短剧。

;

;;“不确定性”;

;

;然而，微短剧市场也面临着种种问题。

;

;大量影视公司乃至平台，目前并不愿意在这块业务上过于高调，核心在于微短剧在政策上依旧存在不稳定性。

;

;短剧的规范化监管可追溯至2020年8月，广电总局在重点网络影视剧信息备案系统增设了网络微短剧快速登记备案模块，标志着微短剧正式纳入监管体系。

;

;2022年4月，广电总局发文明确将包括短剧在内的国产网络剧片审查纳入行政许可事项管理，需要取得相关广播电视行政管理部门的发行许可才能播放上映; 当年11 月，针对小程序微短剧，发文开展专项整治。

;

;在引导规范化发展的同时，广电总局也给予短剧必要的支持，2022年12月，《关于推动短剧创作繁荣发展的意见》提出要培育壮大短剧创作主体，在资源、人才、营销、排播、宣传等方面对短剧进行倾斜性支持。  

;

;必须注意的是，目前，爽剧仍是该市场主流。据巨量引擎，当前短剧以“爽”为内核，90%的题材都以“爽”为主，爽的方式多样，包括战神、穿越、逆袭、重生等题材。由此，呈现“媚俗化”倾向。据21世纪经济报道记者了解，对于大量“擦边”内容，监管层正在关注中。

;

;“市场走向充满着不确定性。”多位行业上下游参与者如此表态。

;

;另从市场规模来看，微短剧相对长视频还是有限。

;

;在2022年，单爱奇艺一家营收就达到290亿元，同比下滑5%。这一数据，远超同年微短剧总体市场规模，且接近2023年微短剧预计规模。

;

;当下，短剧终端盈利主要分为三种。分别为会员付费、广告变现和电商带货。会员付费包括定期的会员费和单部剧集购买，主流长视频平台单月会员价格在22-25元，短剧专属平台会员费更高，在30元左右；单剧付费收费标准为1-3元/集，爆款剧单集收费可达10 元。广告收入也是短剧收入的重要组成部分，包括贴片广告、广告植入、IP 授权营销；其中，贴片广告是长视频平台的专属，软广植入是短视频平台的常用方式。

;

;总体来看，此种盈利模式依旧趋向短平快，离真正的成熟商业模式还有距离。
